thread.title: NFL notes: Cam Heyward will shelve 'Ironhead' eye black - Football
thread.title_full: NFL notes: Cam Heyward will shelve 'Ironhead' eye black - Football - NorthJersey.com

author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS |
title: NFL notes: Cam Heyward will shelve 'Ironhead' eye black - Football
text:
Cam Heyward is done fighting with the NFL over writing his father’s nickname on his eye black.
Buy this photo Cam Heyward called a truce with the NFL over the eye black that honored his dad, Craig "Ironhead" Heyward. The Pittsburgh Steelers defensive end released a statement late Tuesday that he met with NFL officials after the league fined him for writing "Iron" and "Head" on the black under each eye in consecutive weeks.
Former Passaic High School star Craig "Ironhead" Heyward played 11 seasons in the NFL after a standout career at Pitt. He died of cancer in 2006.
Cam Heyward says he was simply trying to pay tribute to his father and others affected by cancer. He writes that he had a "respectful" exchange with the league and doesn’t want to be a distraction to his team.
Heyward will wear plain eye black going forward and has started an initiative with EyeBlack.com to help provide money for cancer research.
MARIOTA SITS: Titans quarterback Marcus Mariota did not practice Wednesday, giving the sprained MCL in his left knee a day of rest. The rookie was not wearing any protective gear on his injured leg as he talked about playing Sunday.
Mariota said he would wear a brace if he must. He also said his chances of playing against the Atlanta Falcons are pretty good, and he’s keeping up with treatment and preparing as if he’ll start his sixth NFL game.
"You’ve got to be able to show that you buy into what’s going on here, and I’m going to do my best to make sure that I’m prepared and hopefully can go on Sunday," Mariota said.
Mariota sprained the ligament when he was hit low by Dolphins DE Olivier Vernon in last week’s 38-10 loss to Miami, and Vernon said Wednesday the NFL fined him for the hit. It’s the same knee Mariota sprained in 2013 at Oregon, and he played the final four games that season wearing a brace.
’SKINS’ INJURIES: Redskins left tackle Trent Williams and tight end Jordan Reed have returned to limited practice as they go through the NFL’s concussion protocol.
Coach Jay Gruden says neither player has been cleared for contact, and both will visit an independent neurologist later in the week.
Gruden also expects wide receiver DeSean Jackson to be out for Washington’s game against Tampa Bay on Sunday, calling a quicker return from his hamstring injury "a long shot."
JACKSON IN CRASH: Seahawks running back Fred Jackson will play tonight against San Francisco after being examined by the team following a minor car crash.
Jackson participated in the team’s walkthrough practice before departing to face the 49ers. It’s the second car accident the Seahawks are dealing with after fullback Derrick Coleman was involved in a two-car crash last week that led to his arrest for investigation involving charges of vehicular assault and hit-and-run.
Jackson’s accident happened Tuesday night near the team’s facility. The Renton Police Department said that shortly before 5 p.m., Jackson lost control of his 2016 Chevrolet Corvette as he drove down Seahawks Way. A stop sign and street signs were knocked over in the wreck. Jackson’s vehicle sustained moderate front-end damage.
Carroll said Jackson was ticketed and he’s confident no other players were involved.
